comments.author: BenCodie
comments.body: It won't be a game changer however it might create a new wave of demand, as this does create an incentive for institutions to purchase Bitcoin and borrow against it so that they can continue to use the liquidity, and on an institutional level with a well established entity. It would be a lot better and less worrying from a security standpoint if this mechanism wasn't made by blockstream and instead worked on-chain/was a dapp on Bitcoin.

comments.author: cr1776
comments.body: The devil is in the details.Â  How secure is your collateral?Â  There were a lot of companies touting the ability to earn income from your bitcoin a few years ago and they didn't end well.Â  Hopefully blockstream has it figured out, but until they release specific details and the actual prospectus for the funds I am skeptical.Â  If it is (a) secure, (b) widely available, and (c) increases the amounts available for the loans it will help a lot of large bitcoin holders (e.g. even MSTR) to have liquidity for their holdings without having to distrust the market and pay taxes on gains when it is needed.

So, it doesnâ€™t really make sense to borrow fiat or other crypto and use Bitcoin as collateral.With Trumpolini in power for the next 4 years this does not surprise me - you'll shortly understand why.Fun Facts:Â 1. In the US, income from a loan is not a taxable event whereas selling crypto for fiat IS a taxable event.Â 2. As long as you pay back the loan everybody is happy - you got tax-free fiat from your collateral to play around with while hopefully paying less in interest than you would have in taxes if you just had cashed out plus you got your collateral back and the loan company makes their money from interest on the loan.Â 3. If you do NOT pay back the loan the loan company sues you, forecloses on your loan and you lose your collateral - boo hoo - you still got all of that tax-free fiat and the loan company (hopefully) makes more from selling/using your collateral than they would from you repaying the loan. If you do not care about losing your collateral - like say it is an over-valued business or property you own and even better, if said collateral is heavily financed by investors - you stand to make a lot of tax-free money.Number-2 is one of the favorite ways 'The Rich' can avoid taxes on their money and is how it usually works.But, then there is #3... It is certainly Trumpolini's favorite scheme - he and his companies have been sued & foreclosed a myriad of times over the years for doing this. A large part of the kerfuffle in his New York cases is based on him constantly & drastically over-valuating his properties leading to banks losing money on his loans when they try to sell or reinvest the collateral...At least when using crypto for collateral one cannot cook the books to make it appear to be worth more than it really is worth.
